DOC.HEAD: Judge's Ad Finds Delinquent Parents
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-five people responded to a judge's newspaper ad that they'd be jailed for not paying child support unless they appeared in court. Judge Stephen E. Levin had placed an ad in the Philadelphia Daily News a week ago, listing 142 people accused of delinquency in child support payments. The judge's message: Appear in court Friday or ``YOU WILL BE JAILED!'' ``This is an experiment, and I think it's worked out very well,'' Levin during a break between cases. The ad, which cost the court $5,525, listed 136 men and six women and offered ``ONE LAST opportunity to appear and work things out.'' In addition to the 40 people in court Friday, 15 others had surrendered earlier in the week and resumed support payments. Several men waiting their turn said they had been alerted to the ad by friends. ``When I went to cash my check, the guy told me,'' said an electrician who declined to give his name. ``I couldn't believe they put it in the paper. I felt like I had murdered somebody or something.'' The man said he fell behind in his support payments for his 9-year-old after losing his job about two years ago and then ``got scared and took off'' when a bench warrant was issued for his arrest. Many of those waiting to be heard Friday were angry and said the ad had embarrassed them and their families. ``They printed my father's name on the list and he is very embarrassed. My name is Joseph Ciambella Jr., and they left off the `junior,''' the younger Ciambella said. ``I'm the one who hasn't paid my child support, and it's because I haven't seen my son, who's 5, in two years. My mother and father have only been able to see him five times since he was born.'' Levin said if the ad proves to be cost effective, he will run others. ``These people are really afraid. What will happen is that a lot of people who would have totally ignored us will pay what they owe in child support,'' he said. ``It is clear that there will be some people on the list who are not deadbeats, but they will be rare exceptions,'' he added.
